Review Text: Review PROS: Focus is on the amount of air being moved versus battery capacity. It added 3 PSI to all 4 of my my P235/55R19 tires for my hybrid Tucson in about 6 - 7 minutes total as the airflow is a fast 35 LPM. It has a nice long air hose that is almost 20 inches and it is the screw type Schrader valve which I've been looking for. I have large hands and I am a Sr. Citizen. By the time I find the Schrader valve on the tire it's buried inside the fancy wheel rims that come with the SUV. So I prefer the screw on type as I lose less air than I do with the clip on type. I am not enamored with the clip on type which is using a plastic lock and I really question how long that will work and not break. This is why I bought this model versus the newer model that actually has 45LPM and it comes with a storage case for the same price as I paid for this model. The manufacturer claims 40 minutes continuous battery use which is more than enough to fill ~ 20 tires but that's based on smaller tire dimensions, usually they are quoting 16 or 17-in width tires versus my 19-in. Many of my retired friends feel the same way as it's much easier for us to deal with the screw on Schrader valve than it is the press on lock type hose fitting. If the new model had the screw on type I would have bought that as it would have saved me some money but that's how strongly I feel about having the screw on type air hose. With the reduced amperage on the battery it makes it much lighter and also smaller. I found the case that holds all the fittings in the air hose in a much smaller dimension case that easily fits into my Tucson or RAV 4 glove boxes. It has a bag to hold all the cords and attachments. It has strong air transfer claiming 4X faster air transfer which is the key thing. (Who needs four hours of continuous battery capacity?? At that point I'll pull out my small air compressor and get it all done < half that time)! I attached a photo of the new case versus the old case I procured for a different model that had a 25,000 aMh battery so that was the case that fit for that type of unit The display is bright and pretty intuitive settings on thev AP1001. I have updated my review to five stars for two reasons: I used this on a recent road trip to Oregon and California. I aired up my tires four times and the battery was still charged up enough to NOT be in the red. Also the customer service as mentioned by a few people is very good. I called to register this product for the warranty which is 18 months and they actually upgraded to 2 years which is one of the better warranties out there. CONS: the new model uses the press on type connector versus the screw on air hose. Plus the new model is the same price as the old model with better performance and an includes a storage case with it. It would also be nice to come with the cigarette lighter extension so you had dual power as many of the other competing models do but not that big of a deal to me.

Many of my retired friends feel the same way as it's much easier for us to deal with the screw on Schrader valve than it is the press on lock type hose fitting. Review Text:
The Airmoto Tire Inflator Portable Air Compressor is a handy and efficient solution for keeping your car tires properly inflated, especially when you're on the go. Whether you're on a long road trip or just need a quick top-up after noticing a slow leak, this compact device offers a lot of convenience for such a small package.
 

 Design and Build: The first thing you'll notice about the Airmoto Inflator is its compact and portable design. At just about the size of a water bottle, it’s easy to stash in your car's glove compartment, trunk, or even under the seat without taking up much space. The build feels solid for its size, with a durable plastic exterior that can handle some bumps and scrapes.
 

 Ease of Use: Using the Airmoto is straightforward. It comes with an easy-to-read LED display that shows the current tire pressure and allows you to set your desired pressure. The built-in preset options for various tire types (like car, bike, or ball) make it even more user-friendly. The hose is long enough to reach all four tires without feeling like you’re stretched too thin. There’s also a nice touch with the built-in LED light, making it easier to use at night or in low-light conditions.
 

 Performance: When it comes to performance, the Airmoto Tire Inflator delivers. It has a maximum pressure of 150 PSI, which is more than sufficient for most car tires, bike tires, and other inflatables like balls or air mattresses. Inflation speed is decent – it can take a few minutes to fully inflate a car tire from a low PSI, but it’s efficient enough for emergency situations. It’s not as fast as larger, more powerful compressors, but for a portable, battery-operated device, it’s more than acceptable.
 

 Portability: One of the standout features of the Airmoto is its portability. Unlike many other air compressors that require a car's power outlet, this unit is rechargeable via USB-C, so you can charge it at home or even using a portable power bank. The fact that it doesn’t need to be plugged into your vehicle makes it ideal for situations where you’re away from home or need to top off a tire while parked on the side of the road.
 

 Battery Life: The rechargeable battery is a bit of a mixed bag. While it holds a charge long enough to inflate one or two tires, don’t expect to run through a full set of four tires before needing a recharge. It’s great for quick, emergency use, but you’ll need to plan ahead for longer inflation tasks.
 

 Accuracy and Reliability: The built-in pressure gauge is accurate enough for everyday use, though it may differ slightly from high-end, professional gauges. For the average driver, it provides reliable readings, and the automatic shutoff feature when the desired pressure is reached is a huge plus – no need to worry about over-inflating.
 

 Conclusion: Overall, the Airmoto Tire Inflator is a solid, portable solution for tire inflation in a pinch. It excels in ease of use, portability, and convenience, making it a great addition to your car emergency kit. While it may not replace a full-size air compressor for heavy-duty or frequent use, it’s perfect for the average driver who needs a reliable tool for occasional tire inflation or other inflation tasks.

 Compact, portable design
 Easy-to-read LED display and preset options
 USB-C rechargeable, no need for a car power outlet
 Built-in LED light for nighttime use
 Accurate pressure readings and automatic shutoff
 Cons:
 

 Slower inflation compared to larger compressors
 Battery life could be improved for multiple tires
 Not as suitable for frequent or heavy-duty use
 Final Verdict: If you're looking for a convenient, easy-to-use air compressor for occasional tire inflation, the Airmoto Tire Inflator is a great choice. Its compact size, ease of use, and portability make it an excellent tool for road trips, emergencies, or everyday maintenance. Review Text: Review PROS: Focus is on the amount of air being moved versus battery capacity. It added 3 PSI to all 4 of my my P235/55R19 tires for my hybrid Tucson in about 6 - 7 minutes total as the airflow is a fast 35 LPM. It has a nice long air hose that is almost 20 inches and it is the screw type Schrader valve which I've been looking for. I have large hands and I am a Sr. Citizen. By the time I find the Schrader valve on the tire it's buried inside the fancy wheel rims that come with the SUV. So I prefer the screw on type as I lose less air than I do with the clip on type. I am not enamored with the clip on type which is using a plastic lock and I really question how long that will work and not break. This is why I bought this model versus the newer model that actually has 45LPM and it comes with a storage case for the same price as I paid for this model. The manufacturer claims 40 minutes continuous battery use which is more than enough to fill ~ 20 tires but that's based on smaller tire dimensions, usually they are quoting 16 or 17-in width tires versus my 19-in. Many of my retired friends feel the same way as it's much easier for us to deal with the screw on Schrader valve than it is the press on lock type hose fitting. If the new model had the screw on type I would have bought that as it would have saved me some money but that's how strongly I feel about having the screw on type air hose. With the reduced amperage on the battery it makes it much lighter and also smaller. I found the case that holds all the fittings in the air hose in a much smaller dimension case that easily fits into my Tucson or RAV 4 glove boxes. It has a bag to hold all the cords and attachments. It has strong air transfer claiming 4X faster air transfer which is the key thing. (Who needs four hours of continuous battery capacity?? At that point I'll pull out my small air compressor and get it all done < half that time)! I attached a photo of the new case versus the old case I procured for a different model that had a 25,000 aMh battery so that was the case that fit for that type of unit The display is bright and pretty intuitive settings on thev AP1001. I have updated my review to five stars for two reasons: I used this on a recent road trip to Oregon and California. I aired up my tires four times and the battery was still charged up enough to NOT be in the red. Also the customer service as mentioned by a few people is very good. I called to register this product for the warranty which is 18 months and they actually upgraded to 2 years which is one of the better warranties out there. CONS: the new model uses the press on type connector versus the screw on air hose. Plus the new model is the same price as the old model with better performance and an includes a storage case with it. It would also be nice to come with the cigarette lighter extension so you had dual power as many of the other competing models do but not that big of a deal to me.
